Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Biomolecular Detection at Polarized Luquid-Liquid Interfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1351253 - Gagnon

The overall goal of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant is to develop inexpensive and portable biosensors for rapid, sensitive and specific label-free multiplexed biomolecular detection. The possibility of miniaturizing biosensing systems which use miniscule quantities of expensive reagents and precious samples, provide faster analyses to patients and doctors, and do not require a trained technician to operate has immediate applications in preventing disease in developing countries, biowarfare/anti-terrorism applications, environmental monitoring, point-of-care diagnostic testing and for basic biological research.

A major obstacle towards accomplishing this goal is the lack of an available biosensor that is rapid, sensitive and specific to small concentrations of target biomolecules, yet does not require the labeling of probes or optical microscopy, and can operate without the need for complex and bulky supporting instrumentation. This project will address existing challenges by focusing on the development of novel electrokinetic biosensors for biomolecular detection at liquid interfaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this CAREER proposal was to integrate the fundamental knowledge generated from the proposed research activities with educational programs designed for students of all levels. During the course of this project we developed a new low-cost portable diagnostic platform capable of detecting real-world biomolecular targets in human serum and whole blood.

The intellectual merit of this proposed research lies in the innovative strategy to develop label-free methods to detect biomolecular interactions in solution at liquid interfaces. It explored the potential benefits that the detection of biomolecules in solution phase can offer in terms of portability, cost, and ease of use over biosensing at solid surfaces.

Broader Impact: The development of biosensors and biosensing transducers capable of sensitive, yet inexpensive and portable biomolecular detection is the foundation for point of care diagnostics. Upon completion of this work, a successful outcome could likely lead to the integration of liquid-based electrokinetic biosensors into portable diagnostic devices for disease and biomarker testing in rural and clinical settings.

Outcomes: During the course of this project we developed the ability to detect biomolecular targets non-optically using interfacial electrokinetics. The idea is to use an external electric field to displace an electrical interface subjected to a biomolecualar reaction. This reaction influences the electrical field-induced displacement and can be used as a sensitive sensing transducer. Project efforts were directed towards understanding the fundamental physical mechanism of electrokinetic motion of the liquid interface. The interface itself was created using an microfluidic T-channel device (see Figure 1). This device was used to drive co-flowing liquid streams down a main microfluidic channel. Targeting binding reactions were driven via diffusion across the interface between the two flows. When an electric field was dropped perpendicular across the interface, the fluid displaced across the width of the microchannel. This displacement response was then used as an indicator and transduction element for biosensing. The main outcomes of this project were based on our ability to develop a fundamental understanding for how this interface is influenced electrically during targeted biomolecualar reactions. We then developed a method to non-optically monitor interface position using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. Finally, we integrated our fundamental understanding with this non-optical approach in order to detect the prescense of a real-world target (human chorionic gonadotropin; hCG) in both human serum and human whole blood (see Figure 2).
